name: The Lord Of Terror - The Diablo Campaign
author: Valerfor

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Let me introduce you to the most addictive single player module ever made for NWN, The Lord Of Terror will eat your nights, whisper in your ears and monopolize your thoughts with it's mystical atmosphere, continues action and brutal fights.

There is a reason why this module has not only be in the hall of fame for so many years but has the most downloads ever on NWN Vault with over 66 thousands! All these come from a single guy that wanted to play Diablo on his PC but in the 3D perspective of NWN. He searched time and again for such a module that would make him loose his sleep like the original game had but found only sub-par imitations that made no justice to the original. Finally one day he took the initiative and decided to learn the toolset and make his own module out of his love for the game. And what a masterpiece he created!

The Lord Of Terror is unlike any other Diablo clone out there, it has all the original sound, the awesome voices, the creeping sound effects in the tombs the original had and more. The overall design tries to stay as close as possible to the original game featuring though many welcoming additions such as extra areas and bosses from the expansions and even Diablo 2. Even the secret cow level is implemented (after you finish the game). Claustrophobic catacombs filled with undead, demons, dragons, hell knights, lich lords and many other bizarre and terrifying creatures, that take you deeper and deeper to the source of evil till you reach the Hell itself and face the lieutenant of the dark lord first and then Diablo himself in an epic battle! During your course there you may or you may not uncover the secrets of the eternal war by the seraphim themselves and gain weapons of ultimate power, make no mistake - you will need them!

Despite it's high magic (about the level of HoTU) setting, the module is very well balanced letting the features of the classes play an important role by themselves, and compined with its good level range (expect to reach level 28-30 by the end) make this module very good for testing of the Epic Builds here. Class features like Divine Might/ Shield - EWS - Evasion, are all very important for the module although as you may have already suspected it is more suitable for Paladin types than say - for Assassins. And here comes another feature of the module straight out from Diablo 2, many of the items themselves (and there are many) are based on their originals with all those awesome naming and powers in a seemingly endless supply. There are so many weapons that are worth to have (including awesome monk gloves) that the module has a distinguished re-playability based of that fact alone! The module also is open-ended not forcing you to take one route or the other giving you the choice to select each area you want to visit for yourself (in a logical manner). Excellent usage of true blackness where darkvision can be a real help is also worth noting. The Lord Of Terror is sufficiently long, expect to spend more than 30 hours of solid gameplay before you reach the end of it.

For those classes that operate better with someone else nearby as a shield, the module offers the choice of four seperate henchmen, each with his own sub quest, that you can equip as you like (or as your pocket allows). For better visuals and more it uses the CEP as well (the 1.50 version) and many armors/weapons/monsters use that fully in order to deliver a superb experience. It can also be played as a multi player experience if you like, playing with your friends against the forces of darkness and trying to survive the intense combat.

Before i give you the link to the actual module please make yourself a favour and use also those very important Haks for your NWN. Tony's AI and NWNQ. No NWN folder must be without them anymore, and if you want put the Undead Override there as well, makes a ton of difference, trust me.


The Lord Of Terror site --> http://nwn.tolitz.com/

The Lord Of Terror module --> https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... o-campaign

NWNCQ project --> https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... cq-project

Undead override --> https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... dead-redux

Henchman Inventory & Battle AI Mod --> https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... tle-ai-mod


Happy gaming!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Thanks! I just started yet another replay of the Aielund Saga, but now I know what I want to play next.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: Yes, it is a great hack 'n slash module with monster spawns galore. The atmosphere is very close to the original game. Some of the boss battles can be very challenging.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
This probably will be the next module I play. If I get it to run properly on my WIN 10 machine, that is (in the comments on the vault people mention having issues with the module crashing on saving and stuff). I best start with modules with no or low role-playing and save the RP-heavy ones for later. Makes it easier to learn optimizing my characters, step by step.

So I would guess social skills like Bluff or Persuade are not used here?
While it might be useful to have things like Lore or UMD I would assume. Appraise probably won't be necessary when treasure availability is like in Diablo (where you often found the best stuff in the dungeons anyway).

To sum up what I have read here: Will get you to level 28-30. Pally-types would make most sense, while feats like Divine Might, Divine Shield, EWS (as I get it, all weapon types are available), Evasion and Darkvision will be helpful... I will check for possible class combos and if the module runs properly on my computer, then come up with a request (for general guidance, *not* for a complete build) in the Requests section during the next days.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I forgot about this. I never did play it. I need to plan a build for it and insert it in my list of builds to play.

It looks like this needs updating with links to the new vault.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The module is updated with links to the new NWN Vault.
Music & Hak-Pack files are now located in a single place so the redundant links were removed from the description.

This is a true hack & slash module and non-combat skills are rarely (if ever) used.
There are four companions to take with you in your adventures, each with a personal quest.
Paladins, Clerics, Monks & Fighters are best suited to this module but any strong spellsword will also fare well.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: When I finish MTS, I have a Fighter / Bard / RDD similar to the one I am playing now planned for this, followed by Sands of Fate.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Got it to run without problems, with all the fancy Overrides. No crashes or strange-looking tiles. (Using my old Platinum here, as they are still working on EE.)

Not sure what the Henchman AI does, but I had a short test run with a Druid build... while normally henchies or animal companions have a tendency to rush into battle head over heals and are suicidal, during that short test run I suddenly had to deal with a cowardly brown bear who ran away a bit more often than would have been necessary. And still didn't always do what I wanted... lol...

Looks great, especially with NWNCQ and the Undead Redux.

It is impossible, of course, to build an NWN module that is the same as Diablo. Totally different game engine and ruleset, won't work. But the author caught the atmosphere very well here.
And even though I am not that far yet, I would agree with Valerfor that lawful stup... I mean LG types make the most sense here.

Appraise is not used at all.
Persuade can save you a bit of cash, and you might need it to get one of the Henchies when you alignment is not lawful (know that from my test run with the druid, with the other characters I am running through, I solo as much as I can), but probably is not really necessary.
Alignment shifts are such a thing (what counts as good and what as lawful, I sometimes don't really get it), but when you are LG (and not NG or N and depend on it), it is easy to avoid shifts in the "wrong" direction (not sure if there are enough of these to actually change your alignment anyway).

So far, I would say, The Lord of Terror definitely is recommendable!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I was going to play as a Chaotic Good Fighter / Bard / RDD, but Bards cannot be Lawful. Chaotic Good is often hard to play because I try to do something chaotic, but the game says I was being evil,or I try to do something good, but the game says I was being lawful.

Is being lawful so important that I need to rethink my build?

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: I was going to play as a Chaotic Good Fighter / Bard / RDD, but Bards cannot be Lawful. Chaotic Good is often hard to play because I try to do something chaotic, but the game says I was being evil,or I try to do something good, but the game says I was being lawful.

Is being lawful so important that I need to rethink my build?
I can relate to that. In some modules (including the OC) what I would consider to be chaotic, sometimes counts as evil, pffft (like when you spare the fallen ranger or the minotaur in chapter 2...) In other modules, including SoU, what I would consider to be good counts as lawful. And when trying to play chaotic good, I do not know which is worse, evil or lawful...

Better ask Valerfor. I am not that far into the module yet. The shifts towards lawful I got so far wouldn't be enough to change your alignment from neutral to lawful yet. There are a few occasions to save townsfolk from getting killed in the dungeons. When you manage to save them and tell them to flee and that you will handle it afterwards, you get +1 lawful and a couple XP, 250 when you are level 3, 200 when you are level 4 or something. I have no idea how many of them you will encounter later on (the only character so far who never failed to save them was yours, by the way).

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I am playing this next after finishing MTS. I was going to play a Fighter / Bard / RDD with no weapon-specific feats like Weapon Focus, using the +8 STR from RDD to compensate. This would make him equally effective with all melee weapons (45 AB at level 40). With all this fuss about lawfulness being so important, I have changed my mind. Instead, I will play with this customized verison of my Order of the Wyrm build:

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Why don't you just do a short test run?
You best talk to everyone once before you enter the church anyway, and then you will see how the module builder handles alignment shifts.
It shouldn't take too long until you have gotten a general impression, and then you still can change your mind.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I'll do something like that after I finish MTS.

posts.content:

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content: From what I have seen, the blacksmith is selling all kinds of weapons, including scimitars.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: That's why I went ahead and chose scimitar. I am level 5 and I have finished the second level of the cathedral and saved the water supply.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Here we are having finished level 3 and ready to go to the King's tomb:

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Looks like I might have to give this one a whirl after I've finished Dragon Age. I'm wondering about a Monk/Rogue/CoT build, but I wonder whether a DEX-based dual-wielder (possibly halfling or elf) would work alright? If not, I may go STR-based thumper (maybe dwarven - I'm bored with being human atm).

Would welcome your thoughts before I sharpen my pencils.

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
The story takes place in the town where you were raised, and everybody else in town is human.

Here's a Rogue 19 / Monk 11 / Fighter 10 that I have played twice, once in SoU + NS + HotU + SoF and again in the OC + Aribeth's Redemption and then in MTS (starting as he was at the end of the OC). WS/EWS is especially nice to have as a DEX-er. I made the build back when I thought it was a good idea to take Toughness at level 1, so that needs moved. Any other race would have an experience penalty, except Halfling, who would get an attack penalty with a kama in his off-hand just like a Human would using a longsword in his off-hand.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Both interesting Empyre, thanks. I hadn't even considered going ranged (the second build) - that would make a nice change: iirc it's about 18 months since I was last a shootist. I notice you take Improved Sneak Attack as a Rogue bonus feat (at level 37), and I can't remember if that can be applied to ranged attacks. If not, would Slippery Mind be a reasonable idea, to help with the low Will save?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: You can definitely get Sneak Attacks with a bow (if you're within 30 feet of the target), and Improved Sneak Attack adds another d6 to that damage. By the time you get to level 37 in such high-magic environments, you will probably have something that will give Immunity to Mental Effects, anyway.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Every time I go to Imgur to upload a screenshot, I wind up spending hours looking at the pictures there. It is quite a time sink, although enjoyable, so that is why I don't post pictures here very often. Here I am standing in front of a door labeled "To Hell", having done everything I could find elsewhere to do first:

I chose those helmets because of what they do, and despite their appearance.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: And how has it been for you so far, Empyre? Enjoyable?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: It has been mostly enjoyable. I have an amulet that protects against mental effects and another that protects against level / ability drain, but there are enemies that use both kinds of attacks. I haven't found either kind of protection on anything else (a helmet, a ring, etc), so I can only protect against one or the other, and that is a little bit frustrating.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: It has been mostly enjoyable. I have an amulet that protects against mental effects and another that protects against level / ability drain, but there are enemies that use both kinds of attacks. I haven't found either kind of protection on anything else (a helmet, a ring, etc), so I can only protect against one or the other, and that is a little bit frustrating.
They're my two biggest hates as well. Personally, I'd go for the mental protection - at least you'll be able to use scrolls (assuming they're available) of restoration afterwards, or glug potions during combat. I suppose one could argue you could do the same with Clarity pots, but they've got a rubbish time limit for bigger fights. Anyway, that's just me. Of course, as you take more CoT levels your Will saves will improve dramatically (it does still irk me, though, that stun doesn't seem to count as a mental attack in NwN).

Regardless, glad you're having a (mostly) good time!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: There is a ring also (from the witch) if I remember correctly...

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: There is a ring also (from the witch) if I remember correctly...
Aha! ! was looking for mental effects immunity on something else, forgetting to look for level/ability drain immunity. Also, it is listed last on that ring, after a few effects that I didn't need.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: It turns out that there is a much cheaper ring that has only Immunity to Level / Ability drain. I didn't think to look on the bottom row, assuming that something so useful would be more expensive.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Right, it is a simple bone ring (or the cloak of black-flame), both are inexpensive items.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Here we are having just killed Diablo:

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Nice Job!

Overall impressions, most memorable fight?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
It isn't perfect in every way, but it is a lot of fun. I will play it again, and I recommend it.

Early on, in the Cathedral, there are a lot of locked barrels that sometimes explode when you bash them. That is why I started over as a Rogue, but then i discover that they are set to require a specific key (which doesn't exist), and the explosions are scripted, so my Rogue couldn't disarm or even find the trap. That was annoying, but it was only in the Cathedral.

The fight that stands out in my mind as the toughest was not the final one with Diablo, but the one not long before in the Armories of Hell. There were so many enemies that they overwhelmed me. If they weren't so strangely fixated on attacking that armor stand, I don't think  I would have made it. As it is, it took several tries.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Yes, I remember that one, good fight and there it was that I acquired "Breath of the Undying" if I remember correctly. The fight with the Archangel was also good, it is where you learn the truth about the ongoing war with heaven & hell.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I don't remember fighting any angels. That must be a quest I missed, although I did try to explore everywhere. I also never found the black mushroom for the witch.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
The mushroom was in the Caverns, level 1, but I wouldn't have found it either if I hadn't checked with the toolset. I knew it must be there, it was in the first level of the Caverns in the original Diablo after all... You didn't fight Izual?

I vividly remember the battle with Lazarus. Took quite awhile. Always teleported away, and when I thought I had him, he healed himself...

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I could well be that I fought Izual. I don't remember the names of everybody I fought. Probably unrelated, but I remember getting a heart, and the game said that somebody might find it useful, but I never found who wanted it.

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content: I've been trying to install this for about 24 hours now. Every time I try to install the CEP files I then get a runtime error message. I've been trying to install the older version CEPs that are linked to on the NW vault LOT page. I had the latest CEP installed but ended up deleting all my game files and reinstalled NWN because the folders were all so cluttered. I feel like I'm following the instructions. I've been doing this stuff for many years now but like my playing my mod installing is still pretty poor. Any tips appreciated.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: This module is very old, and it uses CEP 1.x. CEP 1.x can be installed side-by-side with CEP 2.x, and they won't step on each other's toes. Also, on the Vault page for LoT, it should say what other files are required and give links.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Right, the older CEP versions do not conflict and are separate in a manner from the 2.XX+ versions.  You need the older ones for Lord of Terror and some other noteworthy modules.

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content:
Thanks

sorted it by changing the compatibility settings in the end which I haven't had to do in the past that I can recall. Cool module. Had to dial it back to D&D hardcore difficulty. Taken 2 levels of paladin and 3 of cleric. Low strength means I had to take a henchman. Going to take zen archery and keep taking cleric levels as I go. Really immersive play so far. I never played Diablo so it's all very new to me.

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Let me introduce you to the most addictive single player module ever made for NWN,"
Totally agree

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content: Does anyone know if it is possible to implement a character customisation override like this one into this module? I'm loving it but my half-orc Faithful of Gruumsh is looking odd walking around in a lightest tan cloak :) https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... e-hak-ccoh

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Try this on your save game file man, I think this is how I was able to fix mine as well.

Cloak Converter --> https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... -converter

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content: I thought I'd try the ranger henchwoman out but have discovered that she is about as useful as tits on a bull. Ended up having to spend half the time healing her. Gave the wizard a go but he was slaughtered in the first encounter. I walk a lonely road.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: So far I have played this only twice, and I used used the fighter hench both times, and he is very useful, but I might consider trying the monk sometime. Remember to keep your hench as well-equipped as you are in modules like this where you can access their inventory.

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:So far I have played this only twice, and I used used the fighter hench both times, and he is very useful, but I might consider trying the monk sometime. Remember to keep your hench as well-equipped as you are in modules like this where you can access their inventory.
Yeah I tried kitting the ranger out with a bit of gear so she could help in the forest for a bit of RP flavour. She was accurate with her arrows from a distance but some enemies would always break off and go after her. Even with SL armour +4 she just gets owned by everything. I suppose I'll need to splash out for an amulet, cloak and rings too instead of being a miser. Also, I might be going in too soon but my fighter 9 WM 2 seems to easily crush everything in his path.

Sent from my G3125 using Tapatalk

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content:
*Minor Spoiler

Anyone know how to access the trapdoor beneath the overgrowth in the SE corner of Tristram? I used the bomb from Lester but then it says to ask him about an incantation to open it. When he is asked this dialogue option doesn't come up.

Sent from my G3125 using Tapatalk

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: You need to talk to The Cow.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Hehe, one of the best little secrets of this module...

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content:
*The dwarf desperately struggles up out of the trapdoor, beard singed, smoking and dripping with acid, then leaps headlong into the creek*

Sent from my G3125 using Tapatalk

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Following discussions elsewhere, I'm about to embark on this for the first time, followed by Sands of Fate.

The build I'm planning on using is a modified version of an old one of mine: Harding Brighwtater

When I say modified, I'm looking at going for Dev Crit, so dropping 2 of LoH, Great Fort, Iron Will, Lightning Reflexes, and Dodge for Power Attack and Great Cleave pre-epic; and the 2 Great Wisdom CoT bonus feats for Overwhelming and Devastating Crits in epic levels (and I might drop the EWF: Kama for a bit of Fire Resistance, as well). All, obviously, with some re-jigging of the feats. I'd also probably take a detection skill instead of Spellcraft, as well as some other skills readjustments.

Now, Harding is a dwarf, so one question is whether a dwarf is acceptable for LoT? If not, I can re-imagine with human, but I'd still prefer a dwarf if possible.

Second question: CEP. Given that I've got the old CEPs for Aribeth's Redemption and Mines of Twin Summit already installed, do I really need to do it again, or should those ones do the job?

Any advice is welcome!

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
It might seem a bit odd RP-wise as the only non-human in town, but I doubt that any NPC will care.

By level 40, the need for fire resistance will be long past, so stick with EWF.  With no armor and no shield, the only metal thing that might burn you in SoF Ch 1 would be a helmet, so wear a cloth hood or fire resistance gear during that time.  I will need to do the same thing because I get RDD 10 a bit late in my build.

For detection skills, Search and Spot are nice in SoF.  Spot is a class skill for CoT, but Search would have to be cross-trained.

Any version of CEP 1 should be fine.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: That's great, Empyre, thanks!

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:Following discussions elsewhere, I'm about to embark on this for the first time, followed by Sands of Fate.

The build I'm planning on using is a modified version of an old one of mine: Harding Brighwtater

When I say modified, I'm looking at going for Dev Crit, so dropping 2 of LoH, Great Fort, Iron Will, Lightning Reflexes, and Dodge for Power Attack and Great Cleave pre-epic; and the 2 Great Wisdom CoT bonus feats for Overwhelming and Devastating Crits in epic levels (and I might drop the EWF: Kama for a bit of Fire Resistance, as well). All, obviously, with some re-jigging of the feats. I'd also probably take a detection skill instead of Spellcraft, as well as some other skills readjustments.

Now, Harding is a dwarf, so one question is whether a dwarf is acceptable for LoT? If not, I can re-imagine with human, but I'd still prefer a dwarf if possible.

Second question: CEP. Given that I've got the old CEPs for Aribeth's Redemption and Mines of Twin Summit already installed, do I really need to do it again, or should those ones do the job?

Any advice is welcome!

Cheers
I would go 20/10/10 and that way you don't need to drop anything for OC and DC. You lose one feat from Monk 25 and gain 3 from Fighter 6, 8 and 10, so you can work it out.


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Maximillian_Kane wrote: ↑
Oct 19, 2020
I would go 20/10/10 and that way you don't need to drop anything for OC and DC. You lose one feat from Monk 25 and gain 3 from Fighter 6, 8 and 10, so you can work it out.
Here we go again, Max! You're right in many ways, but my way gives me immunity to mind spells and Dev Crit before the end of LoT (with the re-jigging, which I'll show later), rather than taking the immunity at level 37ish. I honestly do understand the whys and wherefores, but I'd still rather have it when it's useful for longer. (And, of course, Monk 25 also gives an extra point in AC, and Monk 21 and 24 grant a further collective 20% to speed, and there's the additional +6 to SR. Just saying.)

And so the old debate rumbles ever onward...

Cheers

(And, of course, Monk 25 also gives an extra point in AC, and Monk 21 and 24 grant a further collective 20% to speed, and there's the additional +6 to SR. Just saying.)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Here's the build I'll actually be using. I've kept him as a dwarf, and if any of those damn humans sneer at him, he'll show them what being a dwarven Monk is all about. I have made an assortment of changes, but kept the same split.
SpoilerMonk 26/ CoT 10/ Fighter 4 PvM 1-40









1 M1: Blind Fight/ {Cleave/ Evasion/ etc} 3 M3: WF: Unarmed/ {Monk Speed} 5 M5: {Immune to Disease} 7 M7 9 M9: Lightning Reflexes/ {Imp Evasion} 11 M11: {Immune to Poison} 13 M13 15 M15: WF: Kama/ {Quivering Palm} 17 M16: {d20 fist} 19 CoT3 21 F1: Great Strength I (22)/ EWF: Unarmed 23 CoT5 25 M18: {50% concealment x2 p/day} 27 M20: Great Strength III (25)/ {Immune to mind spells/ DR 20/+1} 29 F3 31 CoT7 33 CoT8: Great Strength IV (28)/ Epic Prowess 35 M23 37 M25: Armour Skin 39 M26: Great Strength VI (31)
The saves are a little worse, but I've managed to get both Spot and Spellcraft in by boosting INT by 2.

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I have a suggestion.  Replace Great Fortitude, Lightning Reflexes, and Toughness with the dual-wielding feats, switch Improved Crit, Overwhelming  Crit, and Dev crit from unarmed to kama, and get EWF kama earlier, at least swapping it with Epic Prowess.  You would then have up to 10 attacks per round to attempt a Dev Crit, and when you face crit-immune enemies, your fists can do a tremendous amount of blunt damage.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks worth some serious consideration, Empyre, thanks! Theoretically, I could postpone EWS: unarmed for EWF in kama, then take that EWS instead of Epic Prowess, which could drop to level 40.

I'll go have a mull...

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: As another option, you could go the other direction and forget kamas altogether, taking Luck of Heroes (moving Blind Fight to 6 and Great Fortitude to 15) and Epic Toughness instead of WF Kama and EWF Kama.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Afraid I need WF: Kama (or some other melee weapon, but Kama retains Monk's UBAB) for access to CoT. It seems we children of 65 are getting the occasional senior moment!

Cheers

posts.author: 0rangeAGENT
posts.content:
I’m thinking about playing a modified version of the Sacred Exorcist for my first attempt at this Module.

http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 22098.html

1. Are there enough Outsiders, and at least 2 of Constructs, Elementals, or Vermin for this build to be worth it?

2. Also, if I added 2+ levels of Paladin, would the trade off of 2 levels of turning and some caster levels, for boosted saves and immunity to disease and fear be worth the cost?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
This build gets Planar Turning well after the end of LoT.  I do remember vermin, but I don't remember any constructs, and I am unsure of elementals.

A couple levels of Paladin might be worthwhile.  It would also let you use martial weapons

posts.author: 0rangeAGENT
posts.content:
It sounds like it might still be a decent build if I got Planer Turning via Evil/Good Domain rather than epic feat. And maybe forgoe the other turning types for Sun Domain. That would also mitigate the turning reduction by taking some Paladin levels.

Hah, I guess it’s not the same build at all by this point.

posts.author: eltalstro
posts.content:
I'm on my phone and can't figure out how to hide spoilers but I can't answer the question without minor spoilers. Read past here at your peril.

There are a lot of outsiders/elementals later in the game. The creator has given them the Diablo names to simulate the original game. For instance some elementals are labelled as demons but I can't imagine he has gone further than renaming them. I don't even know if you can switch a creature's type. Some creatures labelled as "demons" are not demons at all in NWN. But in the mid to late game, yes, there are plenty of outsiders and elementals for you to scare away and then pummel as they cower in a corner.

Sent from my G3125 using Tapatalk

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I got to play for a while today (level 16 Monk right now, see build near the end of the screenshots thread) and I fought vermin, outsiders, and elementals.  i can't post a screenshot now because I must go to bed.

posts.author: sataricon
posts.content:
Late to the party but need to ask What could be a good build for That module?
I like Melee as much as it can and a human.
I was thinking of using the Shadow Priest build which i used to WOG.

What do you think?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: When designing or choosing or tweaking a build for LoT, you need to remember that the game ends at about level 27.  At level 27, SD is only giving you HiPS.  You might be better off without a third c;lass in this case.

posts.author: sataricon
posts.content: I should check out the level 30 section then.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
sataricon wrote: ↑
Jul 17, 2021
I should check out the level 30 section then.
Or you could take your character off to Sands of Fate once you've finished LoT - that will take you to level 40, and is designed to begin when you're around level 27. Up to you.

Cheers

posts.author: sataricon
posts.content:
So i'm playing the module now and want to ask something in regards to a quest.
SpoilerI'm searching for the bandits brother but i searched the entire forest for him "even killed a dragon" but can't seem to find him at all. Any idea?
Amazing mod.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Spoiler I don't know what triggers that cave to open.  It is either a certain something you do, as a certain level you reach.  In each play-through, it has always eventually opened for me. BTW, there should be two initially-closed caves.  Have you found the ruins up north, yet? Also, there are several people around  town who will have quests for you, so talk to everybody repeatedly, including a ghost and a  certain cow.

posts.author: sataricon
posts.content:
This had been an amazing Quest so far.
Just amazing module over all in terms of quality and structure.

BTW never played sands of fate but i exported my character from LOT with all his +8 items of mass destruction should i abandon these items when i start in sands of fate to have a challenge?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I have never done that, but you could probably get away with it.  I recommend making a saved game first, in case you change your mind.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
If I remember correctly, if you want to take all your gear into SoF, rather than just what you have equipped, make sure you set the difficulty level no higher than Normal. And, again iirc, if you're at the highest level of difficulty, you'll lose all your gear and gold on transition. You can always crank it up after you arrive in Heliopolis.

There should be some more tips on useful stuff in the Sands of Fate thread.

Cheers

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
If you want to play Sands of Faye afterwards, fire immunity is very  useful, especially in the first chapter.  In that case, I recommend RDD instead of WM, perhaps a Paladin 29 / Sorcerer 1 / RDD 10:
